title: Basic equine care
detail:
• Deworming schedule depending on location
• Hoof care important—pick daily, farrier work every 6-8 weeks
• Teeth may need floating, i.e. rasping down sharp edges (buccal side on upper teeth, lingual side on lower teeth due to side to side grinding motion)

title: Routes of medication administration in horses
detail:
• Oral route
• Nasogastric tube: Common route for administering water, electrolytes, dewormer, mineral oil, antigas meds, or refluxing stomach contents when assessing for colic; placed in the medial ventral meatus and passed into the esophagus when horse swallows (passing confirmed by observing and palpating it along the left jugular groove, and listening to gurgling from the open end and smelling for stomach contents once in the stomach)
• IV injection: Jugular most common, thoracic, ceph, saph can be used for small amounts; perivascular inj leads to damage, esp. w common NSAID banamine

title: Routes of medication administration in horses (cont).
detail:
• IM injection: Tap area a few times, insert the needle only, wait until horse stops reacting, then attach syringe, draw back, inject
• Base of the neck (triangle: nuchal ligament at the top of the neck-cervical vertebrae at the bottom of the neck-in front of shoulder blade, where heel of hand is placed)
• Semitendinosus muscle 1-2 inches below the tuber ischii (buttocks) (stand on the opposite end, inject by reaching to the other side since horse will kick towards the side its stuck)
• Gluteal muscle (top of rump) not recommended due to poor drainage, which can lead to abscess
• Pectoral muscle only for small volumes, not common due to soreness

title: Routes of medication administration in horses (cont).
detail:
• SC injection: Neck
• Intranasal route: Strangles (Streptococcus equi) and influenza vaccines, allows direct application onto mucosa, area of concern
• Inhalation route: Nebulizers and AeroMasks deliver micro-droplets, used for asthma and respiratory disease
• Topical route

title: Catheter placement in horses
detail:
• Into the jugular, except long-term Mila, which goes into lateral thoracic vein; sterile gloves
• Catheter types:
• Angiocath for short-term (1-2 days), catheter-over-stylet style
• Mila and Arrow for long-term (3-4 weeks), catheter-over-guidewire style w butterfly extensions
• Butterfly for regional perfusions of antibiotics
• Insyte catheter w wings for arterial blood gas sample collection during anesthesia
• Flushed w saline every 6 hours
• Heparin 1 mL per 100 mL of saline may be used for patency

title: Equine vaccines
detail:
• Core vaccines
• Tetanus toxoid (annual)
• Tetanus antitoxin (post-exposure in not vaccinated)
• Rabies (annual)
• Equine encephalomyelitis (annual before vector season, 6 mo in high risk areas)
• West Nile virus (annual in spring before vector season)
• Risk-based vaccines
• Equine herpesvirus (6 mo)
• Influenza (6 mo if at risk, annual otherwise) (only reduces severity of illness, doesn’t prevent it)
• Strangles (6-12 mo depending on risk)
• Potomac horse fever (6-12 mo, 3-4 if in endemic area)
• Botulism toxoid (3 doses at 4-week intervals, then annual)

title: Common signs of GI ailments in horses
detail:
• Common signs are restlessness, anxiety, agitation, pawing, pacing, stall walking, flank watching/biting, kicking at abdomen, sweating, getting up and down, rolling, grinding teeth, distended abdomen increased HR and RR
• Possible other signs are MM color change, increased CRT, toxic line on gums, motility changes, bounding digital pulses w increased heat in hoof wall, sawhorse stance, dog sitting, decreased appetite, reflux

title: Common signs of neuromuscular disorders in horses
detail: • Ataxia, depression, circling, head tilt, head pressing, nystagmus, facial paralysis, drooling, incoordination, limb knuckling and toe dragging, muscle wasting, prolapsed third eyelid, seizures, altered behavior

title: Common signs of respiratory diseases in horses
detail: • Coughing, clear runny nasal discharge, purulent discharge in the presence of secondary bacterial infection, depression, anorexia, dyspnea, tachypnea, pyrexia

title: Foot ailments in horses
detail:
• Thrush: Fungal infection caused by Spherophorus neaphorus affecting the frog and causing black slime and bad odor; treated w farrier trimming of frog, cleaning w warm water, applying thrush product, keeping dry
• Abscess: Bacteria bw laminae and hoof wall due to moisture or cracks in dry hoof; drained
• Foreign body: Antibiotics and bandage may be necessary
• Laminitis
• Navicular syndrome

title: Equine therapeutic modalities
detail:
• Extracorporeal shock-wave therapy: Speeds up healing time by increasing blood flow to injured ligament, shin, bone
• Interleukin receptor antagonist protein (autologous therapy): IRAP is a protein that binds to receptors in injured joint; IRAP is collected from whole blood incubated and centrifuged and injected into joint for the purposes of reducing/stopping inflammation cascade in joint inflammation caused by injury or osteoarthritis
• Platelet-rich plasma (autologous therapy): Whole blood centrifuged to separate plasma; used to treat tendon, ligament, and some joint injuries

title: Equine surgery and anesthesia
detail:
• Standing sedation for short surgeries (IV bolus under, CRI above 15-20 min); common meds are alpha 2 agonists like dexmedetomidine, xylazine, or these followed by an opioid butorphanol, morphine
• Preinduction sedation w above alpha 2 agonists w or w/out opioids
• Induction w ketamine (w benzodiazepine and/or guaifenesin), thiopental (w benzodiazepine and/or guaifenesin), tiletamine and zolazepam
• Total IV anesthesia (TIVA) extends anesthesia after induction; short-term w ketamine and alpha 2 agonist, long-term w ketamine plus [xylazine and guaifenesin OR dexmedetomidine OR benzodiazepine]
• Maintenance w iso, sevo, or halothane
• Partial IV anesthesia (PIVA) lowers amount of general anesthetic; dexmedetomidine, xylazine, ketamine, lidocaine 2%, or combinations (ketamine and an alpha 2 agonist, lidocaine and ketamine w or w/out xylazine OR dexmedetomidine

title: Ruminants
detail:
• Cattle, sheep, goat
• Herbivores; diet mainly consists of plants w high fiber (cellulose) content
• Symbiotic relationship w protozoa and bacteria allow digestion of indigestible feed; byproducts of anaerobic fermentation are volatile fatty acids, amino acids, and vitamins, which are used for body maintenance, and methane and carbon dioxide, which are eructated
• True ruminants like cattle have prehensile tongues to gather food
• The hoof (aka ungula): 4 hooves per foot, two are weight-bearing (3rd and 4th digits)

title: Ruminant digestion
detail:
• Four-chamber stomach:
• Rumen/paunch is the main fermentation vat; microbial products are available for digestion
• Reticulum/honeycomb forces material into the rumen or omasum, or regurgitates ingesta during rumination
• Omasum/many plies is filled w muscular laminae that squeezes fluid out of ingesta
• Abomasum/true (grandular) stomach corresponds to stomachs of monogastrics; site for peptic digestion of proteins
• Camelids are functional ruminants; have 3 chambers

title: Abomasopexy
detail:
• Abomasal displacement is common in dairy cows fed high-concentration, low-roughage diets, esp. 6 weeks after calving
• Hypocalcemia, mastitis, metritis, ketosis, lack of exercise can also lead to displacement
• Signs include reluctance to eat, reduced manure output and milk production, elevated HR, dehydration, and gas and fluid accumulation on the right side
• A distinct “ping” on the right or left will tell if it’s right or left displaced abomasum (LDA more common)
• Physical rolling of patient can temporarily correct it, but it will recur; blind tacking or toggle pinning is also possible, but complications (infection, damage to organs) common
• Surgical fixation of abomasum to the body wall (abomasopexy) is best, followed by only roughage diet

title: Celiotomy
detail:
• Exploratory abdominal surgery; performed for generalized abdominal disease, including colic
• Mostly performed via a ventral midline incision under full anesthesia, but flank incision on a standing, sedate patient possible as well
